data.title: RenderTarget3D for DirectX
data.body:
Added support for new class `RenderTarget3D` which works similar to its 2D and Cube counterparts. This feature does not exist in XNA, but actually fits in pretty elegantly into the API.
- Added RenderTarget3D class with DX implementation.
- Added GraphicsDevice.SetRenderTarget(RenderTarget3D, arraySlice).
- Made RenderTargetBinding a little more generic to handle both cube and 3D textures.
-  Fixed bug were Texture3D.Format was not set.

This should be portable to OpenGL desktop systems, but i'm not sure of OpenGL ES platforms.

Also this currently only works by selecting the depth layer to render into on the CPU side via `GraphicsDevice.SetRenderTarget`.  Eventually when we support geometry shaders in MGFX we can also do this on the GPU.

data.title: Fix SamplerState in EffectPass
data.body: This small fix makes it so that the SamplerState defined in an EffectPass is set even if there is no texture assigned to the EffectParameter.

data.title: Fixed missing keyboard mapping for Linux
data.body: The Linux version is missing keyboard mappings for the right shift key, right windows key, and the forward slash key is assigned to Keys.None rather than Keys.OemQuestion.

data.title: Fixed the Matrix.CreateBillboard function so that both overloads work.
data.body: A fix for the broken Matrix.CreateBillboard function.

data.title: Fix for delete BufferRender.  Should only be GLES and not OpenGL.
data.body:
This was causing problems on MacOSX.  I went broad with the change and so after feedback am narrowing it down.

I have tested on Samples and two other frameworks.

Also confirmed with Dean to be working after some discussions with affected parties.

data.title: Allow scaling for METRO/DX/XAML
data.body:
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1487

When setting the backbuffer/swapChain to other than the native
 resolution
 SwapChainBackgroundPanel doesn't get notified.
 One way to force it to update and change the resolution (scaling) is to
 set again the SwapChain.

data.title: Fixing Gesture Infinite Loop
data.body: When the enabled gestures is changed we need to call ReleaseAllTouches(). While testing on iOS I found that changing the EnabledGestures while a drag is occurring on the hardware will result in an infinite loop due to partial state being recorded - the IsGestureAvailable call will loop forever.

data.title: Fixed EffectParameter Bug
data.body:
This is a pretty bad big in effects that occurred when i submitted the change to make all `EffectParameter` data be held in `Array` types by default.  

For the last few weeks effects have been sharing the parameter data... so if data was changed on one the others cloned from it would also be affected.  This fixes that issue by cloning the array on construction.

data.title: Fixed SamplerStateCollection to reset to SamplerState.LinearWrap
data.body: This fixes the issue where the SamplerState is null after the device state is reset.

data.title: Allow scaling for METRO/DX/XAML
data.body:
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1487

When setting the backbuffer/swapChain to other than the native
resolution
SwapChainBackgroundPanel doesn't get notified.
One way to force it to update and change the resolution (scaling) is to
set again the SwapChain.

data.title: Fix for iOS Song's Play/Stop
data.body:
In XNA, calling MediaPlayer.Play() should start a song from it's beginning. AVAudioPlayer does not have the same behavior, and needs it's CurrentTime property set to 0 to emulate this behavior.

Replication steps:
Play a song using MediaPlayer.Play().
Play a second song using MediaPlayer.Play().
Call MediaPlayer.Play() again on the first song played
Bug: First song starts at where it left off, rather than the start.

data.title: Time to Solve the GetData problem
data.body:
Ok we all agree that Writing data from the CPU to the GPU is just bad performance wise so lets come up with all the reasons you'd want to and what can be done instead

Collision detection: As has been said before just do this with off screen data.
Screen Capture: Best solution I have to this would be to create a sub class of `RenderTarget2D` that internally stores it's data "CPU side" (aka doesn't actually draw to screen ever) so reading it back is much quicker.

Any other use cases?

data.title: [Android] GetData on Nexus 7 leaves graphics in weird state
data.body:
GetData on the Nexus 7 is not supported. So if you capture the GL error (InvalidEnum) and attempt to recover, you can't. The blending state is so distorted that the screen flickers between updates and your sprites have no blending (all black) and appear as black boxes. Eventually the draw ceases to work properly but the game continues.

I am adding this issue as a reminder that GetData is dicey business and that there is a side effect should GetData fail.

data.title: Samples are Broken
data.body:
Currently allot of the samples are broken or not implemented for many of the platforms. 

The Samples are hosted at https://github.com/CartBlanche/MonoGame-Samples.

To work on the Samples you should fork the master on that repo and submit pull requests to that repository.  

Note there is a SamplesContentBuilder project in the Samples repo to build the required .xnb files for Fonts, Textures , Effects etc, this builds the data to the CompiledContent directory. you will find .xnb files for each platform in that directory. When updating a sample, if the font/ texture/ Effect does not exist in the Content Builder it should be added and compiled for each platform. The resulting .xnb file should be added to git and commited along with you other changes.If possible use existing fonts and assets for the sample. The ContentBuilder is dependent on having the 3.0.x release installed.

Once the .xnb is in place, you can then link to the file from the project as normal. Please when you add it to the project make sure you "add as link" so it does not copy the file locally, we are trying to pull all the assets in the one place.

Once you have a sample working for a platform, please update the following wiki entry

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/wiki/Samples

IMPORTANT : So we can keep track of when someone is working on a sample please put your initials in the relevant box for the sample and platform you are working on. I would advice working on one sample at a time.

data.title: Small change to template file for android (doesn't run on file-> new -> F5)
data.body:
When installing the templates from here http://monogame.codeplex.com/releases/view/102870

When doing file -> new -> Monogame Android, then F5 it doest run due to an error in the using

data.title: A better error message when a ContentTypeReader can no be found using Type.GetType
data.body:
This change has been made in response to a common problem when porting projects. If you suffix your project with the platform name, eg MyGameTypes.Android, this defaults the Assembly name and resulting dll to MyGameTypes.Android.dll. Content types in this assembly can then not be reflected as the Xnb files were build against the project MyGameTypes.dll and hence have a mis-matched full type name.

Reference: http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/435819

data.title: MGFX Large Shader Fix
data.body:
The first thing this does is fix an overflow in loading large shaders.  I have run into two cases where debug shaders can be > 65K and overflow the 16bit size.  This fixes my miscalculation restoring that to a 32bit integer, increments the MGFX version, and rebuilds the stock effects.

Second I took the time to remove old shader code files that are no longer used by the runtime.

data.title: Unit Test Fixes
data.body:
A few simple unit test fixes to make things more pleasant to work with.

First places where `Assembly.GetEntryAssembly()` are used now check for null.  This is because when running the unit tests via the VS IDE with Resharper this method returns null. Why?  Because [according to the docs](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.reflection.assembly.getentryassembly.aspx) `GetEntryAssembly()` can return null when called from unmanaged code which I guess is what it does from VS.  Either way it seems safer to test and costs us nothing.

Second I replaced two places where `Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly().Location` was being used.  The point of this code was to ensure the right path which can find the data files needed for running the tests.  When the "executing assembly" is a unit test runner like ReSharper it does not exist in the same folder as the test data.  `AppDomain.CurrentDomain.BaseDirectory` is the proper way to get the directory where execution started.

Finally I removed an incorrect disposal of GraphicsDeviceManager in WinFormsGamePlatform.  Game already takes care of this for us.

data.title: First overload of CreateBillboard returns incorrect results
data.body:
I'm converting my XNA billboard example projects to run in MonoGame and I think I have found a bug in one of the versions of the Matrix.CreateBillboard function. None of my billboard objects are visible at all in MonoGame, and after spending some time trying to figure out where the invisible scoundrels have gone, I think that Matrix.CreateBillboard looks like the culprit.

I'm calling it with the following parameters:

```
Matrix result = Matrix.CreateBillboard(Vector3.Zero, new Vector3(0.0f, 0.7f, 2.0f), Vector3.Up, Vector3.Forward)
```

Executing this against XNA 4.0 returns a Matrix with the following content:

```
{ {M11:-1 M12:0 M13:0 M14:0} {M21:0 M22:0.9438583 M23:-0.3303504 M24:0} {M31:0 M32:-0.3303504 M33:-0.9438583 M34:0} {M41:0 M42:0 M43:0 M44:1} }
    Backward: {X:0 Y:-0.3303504 Z:-0.9438583}
    Down: {X:0 Y:-0.9438583 Z:0.3303504}
    Forward: {X:0 Y:0.3303504 Z:0.9438583}
    Left: {X:1 Y:0 Z:0}
    M11: -1.0
    M12: 0.0
    M13: 0.0
    M14: 0.0
    M21: 0.0
    M22: 0.9438583
    M23: -0.3303504
    M24: 0.0
    M31: 0.0
    M32: -0.3303504
    M33: -0.9438583
    M34: 0.0
    M41: 0.0
    M42: 0.0
    M43: 0.0
    M44: 1.0
    Right: {X:-1 Y:0 Z:0}
    Translation: {X:0 Y:0 Z:0}
    Up: {X:0 Y:0.9438583 Z:-0.3303504}
```

Executing the same call in MonoGame (3.0.0.0 release binaries) returns the following Matrix:

```
{M11:0.9438583 M12:0 M13:0 M14:0} {M21:0 M22:1 M23:0 M24:0} {M31:0 M32:-0.3303504 M33:-0.9438583 M34:0} {M41:0 M42:0 M43:0 M44:1}
    Backward: {X:0 Y:-0.3303504 Z:-0.9438583}
    Down: {X:0 Y:-1 Z:0}
    Forward: {X:0 Y:0.3303504 Z:0.9438583}
    Left: {X:-0.9438583 Y:0 Z:0}
    M11: 0.9438583
    M12: 0.0
    M13: 0.0
    M14: 0.0
    M21: 0.0
    M22: 1.0
    M23: 0.0
    M24: 0.0
    M31: 0.0
    M32: -0.3303504
    M33: -0.9438583
    M34: 0.0
    M41: 0.0
    M42: 0.0
    M43: 0.0
    M44: 1.0
    Right: {X:0.9438583 Y:0 Z:0}
    Translation: {X:0 Y:0 Z:0}
    Up: {X:0 Y:1 Z:0}
```

Note in particular that the Left and Right vectors are not normalised in MonoGame and are pointing in the opposite directions to the corresponding vectors in XNA.

I looked at the current code in MonoGame's Matrix.cs file and found the two overloads of CreateBillboard. The first of these has a small piece of code that creates an identity matrix and then manipulates its Forward, Left, Up and Translation vectors. After this is a much larger piece of code that has been commented out with no explanation. This is the overload that is returning the wrong matrix.

The second overload (that return the Matrix via an "out Matrix result" parameter) has only the code that has been commented out in the first overload, and appears to be returning the correct value. If I switch my project to use this (much less convenient) second overload, all the particles reappear as expected.

It looks therefore like the current code in the first overload simply needs to be replaced with the commented out code. If I had the faintest idea how to create a pull request then I'd make the change and submit it, but I don't have the free time to figure that out at the moment so I'm hoping someone else can deal with this for me.

data.title: OpenTK Future
data.body:
We need to decide how we want to handle OpenTK moving forward.

The official state of OpenTK is unknown as the sole maintainer has gone MIA, [Is OpenTK Dead?](http://www.opentk.com/node/3217), but that itself is a pretty bad sign of things.

In particular we have a need to fix bugs more than anything else.  But there are needs for supporting new OS features as well.

data.title: Initial window positioning fix for WinGL & Linux (fixes #1414) - DEPENDS ON OPENTK CHANGE
data.body:
The window is created before being resized on WinGL and Linux, which means it's centered based on the wrong initial size. This pull request makes sure the window is properly centered just before the main loop starts.

This pull requests **depends on an OpenTK change**: https://github.com/dellis1972/opentk/pull/1 so we should make sure the binaries are updated before merging otherwise it won't work (it won't break anything but the centering won't work as OpenTK's ClientRectangle setter used to ignore the position)

data.title: Fix #if MACOS to be #if MONOMAC (fixes bugs with content loading & probably audio)
data.body:
There were a couple "#if MACOS" directives in TitleOpenContainer.cs and OpenALSoundController.cs, but MACOS isn't a valid define symbol for any platform. The proper symbol to check against is MONOMAC. The attached commit fixes that.

The bug made all content loading on Mac be relative to the current working directory so I suppose it went undetected because few people are changing the current working directory.

It also made the call to alcMacOSXMixerOutputRate in OpenALSoundController never happen on Mac. Not sure what are the implications of that but I guess it's a good thing it's not ignored anymore.

data.title: Move Test Binaries To ThirdParty
data.body:
- Update the ThirdParty/Libs submodule to use the latest.
- Fixed Tests to use NUnit and NDesk assemblies from ThirdParty/Libs.

data.title: Delete Develop3d Branch
data.body:
We don't have any pull request against the `develop3d` branch anymore.  It seems like we've fully finished the transition over to `develop`.

So how long do we wait before we kill off `develop3d`?

data.title: Fix for #1241 - more than 16383 batch items
data.body:
Supports more than 16383 batch items. Tested with 75000 batch items and with two different textures in the same batch operation. Also refactored the duplicate index initialization code to make it one method used by the ctor and the batch drawing code.
#1241 and #1520 are included in this commit.

data.title: Fbx importer
data.body:
This is the first pass on getting FBX models to import. It supports FBX 2012 and 2013 formats through the Open Asset Import Library and the assimp-net C# wrapper. It should be relatively easy to expand functionality and support many more formats in the future.

It also includes the start of a ModelProcessor. There's no material support yet, just a mesh hierarchy that's not quite ready for prime time.

data.title: SpriteBatcher - reduce duplicated code
data.body: The SpriteBatcher ctor has initialization code in it that copies what ExpandVertexArray has in it. This should be consolidated into a single init method for initalizing the indices in the vertex array.
